title: Lucy Knightley
text:
Lucy Knightley (1742–1791) was a British politician who sat in the <a href="House%20of%20Commons">House of Commons</a> between 1763 and 1784.
Early life.
Knightley was the son of Valentine Knightley of <a href="Fawsley">Fawsley</a>, Northamptonshire and his wife Elizabeth Dummer, daughter of Edward Dummer of Swaythling, Hampshire and was born on 23 February 1742. 
He was educated at <a href="Rugby%20School">Rugby School</a> in 1748 and at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a> from 1755 to 1759. In 1760, he matriculated at <a href="Brasenose%20College%2C%20Oxford">Brasenose College, Oxford</a> on 26 January aged 17. On the death of his father on 2 May 1754, he had succeeded to <a href="Fawsley%20Hall">Fawsley Hall</a>, which he developed in the 1760s by employing <a href="Capability%20Brown">Capability Brown</a> on his gardens.
Career.
He was <a href="High%20Sheriff%20of%20Northamptonshire">High Sheriff of Northamptonshire</a> in 1770–71.
Knightley was returned for <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> for <a href="Northampton%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Northampton</a> at a by-election on 21 November 1763 on the Compton interest. During this period he is only known to have voted once in 1767. He did not stand at the <a href="1768%20British%20general%20election">1768 general election</a>. He is generally described in parliamentary lists as ‘country gentleman’ or ‘Tory’. In a by-election on 14 January 1773 he was returned unopposed as MP for <a href="Northamptonshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Northamptonshire</a>. His voting record shows him to have been very independent. He was returned for Northamptonshire unopposed in <a href="1774%20British%20general%20election">1774</a> and <a href="1780%20British%20general%20election">1780</a>. At the <a href="1784%20British%20general%20election">1784 general election</a> he declined to stand owing to ill-health. He does not appear to have spoken in the House.
Personal life.
He married Catherine Dashwood, daughter of <a href="Sir%20James%20Dashwood%2C%202nd%20Baronet">Sir James Dashwood, 2nd Baronet</a> on 14 April 1764.
Knightley died on 28 January 1791. He and his wife Catherine had no children.
